--- title: "Lab 3: Visualize and wrangle data" subtitle: "Not graded, just practice" date: 2023-09-14 author: Katie Schuler number-sections: true number-depth: 3 --- ::: {.cell} ::: Todays lab will make use of the `ratings` data in the `languageR` package. `glimpse()` of data frame is provided for your reference. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ratings %>% glimpse() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 81 Columns: 14 $ Word almond, ant, apple, apricot, asparagus, avocado, badg… $ Frequency 4.204693, 5.347108, 6.304449, 3.828641, 3.663562, 3.4… $ FamilySize 0.0000000, 1.3862944, 1.0986123, 0.0000000, 0.0000000… $ SynsetCount 1.0986123, 1.0986123, 1.0986123, 1.3862944, 1.0986123… $ Length 6, 3, 5, 7, 9, 7, 6, 6, 3, 6, 3, 8, 10, 9, 8, 5, 9, 5… $ Class plant, animal, plant, plant, plant, plant, animal, pl… $ FreqSingular 24, 69, 315, 26, 19, 24, 53, 74, 155, 37, 118, 15, 26… $ FreqPlural 42, 140, 231, 19, 19, 6, 78, 77, 103, 14, 180, 19, 31… $ DerivEntropy 0.0000, 0.5620, 0.4960, 0.0000, 0.0000, 0.0000, 0.634… $ Complex simplex, simplex, simplex, simplex, simplex, simplex,… $ rInfl -0.54232429, -0.70026465, 0.30900484, 0.30010459, 0.0… $ meanWeightRating 1.4860, 3.3489, 2.1948, 1.3216, 1.4424, 1.3256, 3.047… $ meanSizeRating 1.8912, 3.6275, 2.4730, 1.7597, 1.8660, 1.7737, 3.369… $ meanFamiliarity 3.72, 3.60, 5.84, 4.40, 3.68, 4.12, 2.12, 5.68, 3.20,… ``` ::: ::: ## `More visualization` Given code blocks a, b, and c; and the plot below: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # CODE BLOCK a ---------------------------# ggplot( data = ratings, mapping = aes(x = Frequency, y = meanFamiliarity) ) + geom_point(color = "blue") ``` ```{.r .cell-code} # CODE BLOCK b ---------------------------# ggplot( data = ratings, mapping = aes(x = Frequency, y = meanFamiliarity, color = "blue") ) ``` ```{.r .cell-code} # CODE BLOCK c ---------------------------# ggplot( data = ratings, mapping = aes(x = Frequency, y = meanFamiliarity) ) + geom_point() ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lab-03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Which of the code blocks above generate plot A above?
In plot A above, is the color aesthetic mapped, set, or both?
In plot A above, which of the following aesthetics should we set to make the points more transparent?
In plot A above, which of the following would change the x axis label to "FQ"?
::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lab-03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: In plot B above, which geom(s) are used to represent the data?
True or false, the blue line in plot B above is mapped to the Class aesthetic?
In plot B above, which of the following variables is mapped to the x aesthetic?
True or false, in plot B above, the default statistical transformation in the geom responsible for the red dots is "identity".
Suppse we run the code below. Which of the following plots will be returned?
```r ggplot( data = ratings, mapping = aes(x = Frequency, y = meanFamiliarity, color = Class) ) + geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "red") ``` ::: {.cell .caption-bottom layout-ncol="2"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lab-03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lab-03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-2.png){width=672} ::: ::: Suppose we run the following code block, which plot will be returned?
```r ggplot( data = ratings, mapping = aes(x = Class, fill = Complex) ) + geom_bar() ``` ::: {.cell .caption-bottom layout-ncol="2"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lab-03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lab-03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-2.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lab-03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-3.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lab-03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-4.png){width=672} ::: ::: To generate the facets in the plot below, which of the following lines of code must be included?
::: {.cell .caption-bottom} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lab-03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: To adjust the size of the font to 20pt in the complete theme `theme_minimal()`, what argument should we include?
What would happen if we added the layer `scale_fill_manual(values = c("green", "orange"))` to the following plot? ::: {.cell .caption-bottom layout-ncol="2"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](lab-03_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){width=672} ::: :::
## `Data wrangling` Which of the following `dplyr` functions retuns a data frame?
Which of the following `dplyr` functions takes a number as their first argument?
True or false, the following code blocks are equivalent. ```r # option 1 ratings %>% select(Word, Frequency) %>% glimpse() # option 2 glimpse(select(ratings, Word, Frequency)) ```
True or false, the following code options are equivalent ```r # option 1 ratings %>% select(Word:Class) %>% mutate(Length/Frequency, .after = Class) # option 2 ratings %>% select(Word:Class) %>% mutate(Length/Frequency) ```
Recall that there are two possible values in the `Class` variable in the `ratings` dataset: "animal" or "plant". How many rows would be in the data frame returned by the following code block? ```r ratings %>% group_by(Class) %>% summarise(n = n()) ``` Given the code block in the previous question, what will `n()` do?
True or false, the following code blocks will return the same dataframe ```r # code block 1 ratings %>% select(complexity = Complex) # code block 2 ratings %>% rename(complexity = Complex) ```
Which of the following code blocks will return a dataframe including only the rows in `ratings` for which the Class value is "animal"? ```r # code block a ratings %>% filter(Class = "animal") # code block b ratings %>% filter(Class == "animal") ```
By default the `arrange()` function arranges the rows in ascending order. Which of the following code blocks would arrange the Frequency variable in descending order? ```r # code block a ratings %>% arrange(Frequency, order = "descending") # code block b ratings %>% arrange(Frequency, order = "reverse") # code block c ratings %>% arrange(desc(Frequency)) ```
Which of the following code blocks could be used to return the mean frequency by class? ```r # code block a ratings %>% group_by(Class) %>% summarise( mean = mean(Frequency) ) # code block b ratings %>% summarise( mean = mean(Frequency), .by = c(Class) ) # code block c ratings %>% mean(Frequency) %>% group_by(Class) ```
